sentence.text: A 2- years old boy, offspring of non-consanguineous parents and of a 2nd pregnancy, was referred to the endocrine and metabolic center of the Nemazee Hospital, located in southwestern Iran, for evaluation of short stature.
The patient was born at 38 weeks of gestation by cesarean section and was healthy by Apgar scoring.
Birth weight was 3100 g, length 45 cm and head circumference 35 cm.
He had no dysmorphic features and general physical examination revealed no pathology.
There was no satisfactory length gain after birth, as noticed by his parents.
At the referral time at age 2 years the patient had a weight of 8200 g (-4 SD), a length of 71 cm [-4 standard deviation (SD)].
Fingers of the hand were extremely short and broad with small nails; there was no redundant skin on the fingers (Figure 1).
His feet and toes were normal.
Frontal bossing, low set ears and wrist joint hyperflexibility were prominent features.
All developmental milestones were within normal limits.
Radiographic findings showed curved radius, relatively short ulna, and broad metacarps with wide phalanges.
The vertebrae were of normal size and showed no beaking.
Iliac wings and metatarsal bones were normal (Figure 1).
